Cellphones do not emit ionizing radiation, at all (X-rays etc, that give you cancer). They emit visible light (from the screen), thermal infrared radiation (unless they are cooled to absolute zero) and radio waves (cellular, wifi and bluetooth). None of that is dangerous; it’s at much too low a power to cook your eyeballs. As Stanley says, when the phone is on (not in airplane mode) it transmits every 10 minutes or so to stay in contact with a tower. The closer the tower, the less power it uses (it adapts to the cell size to save battery and to minimize interference with more distant cells). It’s not at all dangerous - there is no physical basis for any biological effect - though if you think it is, the nocebo effect can perhaps make you sick, and worrying can cause stress and physical symptoms.

Of course there is radiations coming from your cell phone and from wifi at all times. Connectivity requires this radiation to continuously be coming to and from your device. However, this radiation is not harmful in any way to people, and that’s why our life expectancy hasn’t suddenly dropped off in the past couple decades as now everyone is exposed to these kinds of radiation, because they are harmless radiation.

Anything that has to keep in touch constantly with the wireless phone system needs to say were it is so there is some communication almost all the time. This does not need to be a strong signal but it is there.
